ratings.comment: Professor Tsui (or as he likes to be called, Professor Chewy) was an amazing guy. Lectures are useful, but not required. He has a great sense of humor, and loves to tell stories that help you understand the concepts better. He knows almost everyones name, and is friendly and accessible outside of class. I would recommend prof. Chewy to everyone.

His lectures are hard to follow and he doesn't introduce topics before talking about them so 90% of the time you're not sure what topic he is trying to teach you. Not helpful in office ours, the class was unnecessarily hard.

This professor will make you think he is nice and funny, but in the tests he will have no regrets to don't give you any point if you don't get the answer he wants the way he wants and give BC and C's to half the class, I am a A student and he just gave me a BC and didn't let me see my final, saying he is not obligated.

Professor Tsui is very caring and wants everyone to succeed. You'll get a handout per class that's good for summarizing the material. When you start to doze off he tells funny personal stories. We had our discussion sections cut and he hosted office hours once a week in a large room to make up for it. He really cares and exams are fair.

Most interesting lecturer I've had at UW. Relates statistics to real life situations and makes it clear what is going on behind the formula. Lecturers are great for conceptual material, but the book is more helpful for solving problems. Gives great handouts that help break down material. Highly recommend.

Although he can be hard to understand at times due to his accent, his teaching style is excellent. If you have a sense of humor you will laugh during every lecture. I would definitely recommend him! Too bad he will not be teaching Stats 301 in the near future.

His lectures follow an interesting format: the first fifty minutes or so are very staccato, disconnected, and confusing. However, those who are able to stay awake till the last 25 minutes are thoroughly rewarded with good examples and helpful explanations.  Unfortunately, he is no longer teaching Stat 301 after fall 2014.

His sense of humor is the only reason to attend the lectures.  It is much easier to learn from the book and from discussion (IF you have a good TA, which I originally did not).  He is a confusing teacher, but sometimes he sings in class.

Good professor.  His accent is a little hard to understand at first, but you get used to it.  Homework complements the material well, and he allows cheat sheets for the tests.  Gives out a lot of hand outs, which can get a little overwhelming, but they're all useful.

He has this humor that only a guy like him could make that funny... very likable guy. (ie. a joke about getting **** before a final wouldn't be nearly as funny from your average prof.)  His English is pretty decent, and the course itself isn't too tough. They allow cheat sheets. Do the HW and you're OK. He's a nice guy.

Good professor who really wants his students to learn. Approaches statistics with a reasoning emphasis, and does his best to make sure you understand statistics rather than just merely knowing how to use the formulas.Tells many stories regarding his life experiences, and relates them to statistics too. He was from Hong Kong.
English is fine. One hw assignment per week. He goes at an easy pace, but isn't a great TEACHER of the material. If you're good at math, it shouldn't be hard.

Tells really funny stories....mostly because they are coming from a short little man with an accent. Class is not bad, but you must put in a good amount of effort if you want an A. (B is not very difficult though)

Class is not tough, but paying attention is when his lectures are all over the place. Fortunately, homework counts for a lot and tests arent that hard.Also, you can tell he really doesn't want to fail anyone, so getting a B or C is pretty cake. Dont let homework difficulty scare you away, he makes it more difficult than exams on purpose

what a cutie! don't be scared of his name, his english is perfectly understandable.  It's not too hard for a stats class,  you get to use full sheets of notes for the tests, plus he is very helpful and talkative if you go to office hours.  he always has cute/funny random stories to tell us.
